Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: WormNet II: Assembling the Annelid Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The more than 16,000 recognized species of annelid worms exhibit immense morphological diversity and include such distinct groups as fireworms, earthworms, bloodworms, and leeches. As sediment feeders, scavengers, and predators, annelids occupy terrestrial and aquatic habitats worldwide and are the most abundant fauna (larger than 1 millimeter) in the deep sea, Earth's most extensive habitat. Annelids have economic importance as bait, pests, invasive species (e.g., oyster borers) and ecosystem engineers. Nonetheless, many fundamental questions about annelids remain unresolved because knowledge of their diversity and evolutionary history is lacking. To fill this gap, this international project will assemble the annelid family tree using a large-scale, multi-tiered approach. The oldest relationships will be examined with high-throughput DNA genome sequencing techniques. Recent relationships will be resolved with multi-gene DNA approaches and a community-based sequencing service that will examine approximately 3000 species.

As one of the few segmented phyla, annelids are integral to understanding animal evolution. This project has significant interdisciplinary implications in fields such as developmental biology, paleontology, marine biology, physiology and evolution. Specimens, data, and educational resources will be publicly available. Extensive human resource development includes training more than 25 undergraduates, 5 graduate students and 4 postdoctoral researchers at four institutions, and recruitment of underrepresented groups. K-12 outreach will foster broad scientific participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this collaborative research award was to clarify the evolutionary relationships among annelids (segmented worms) at several levels, from higher-level relationships among major groups to complexes of closely related annelid species. The focus of our lab was Clitellata, a major annelid group that includes earthworms, leeches and thousands of other primarily freshwater and terrestrial species. We generated transcriptome data for ~100 annelids, and have used these data to elucidate relationships in two clitellate subgroups – earthworms (Anderson et al., in press) and Branchiobdellida (crayfish worms; Williams et al., in prep) – as well as in Clitellata as a whole (Erséus et al., in prep). Our earthworm study strongly suggests that two major earthworm lineages diverged in concert with continental break-up in the early Jurassic, ~180 million years ago. These data are also part of a large-scale analysis of relationships among all major annelid groups (Halanych et al., in prep), and are forming the basis for a doctoral dissertation investigating the molecular evolutionary processes involved in transitions between marine, freshwater and terrestrial habitats (e.g., Horn et al., submitted). We also investigated annelid evolution at lower taxonomic levels using a standard set of mitochondrial and nuclear gene sequences. Many annelid species are actually complexes of closely related, anatomically similar species, and in collaboration with researchers in Sweden, France and Iran, we have analyzed relationships within several of these complexes, including in the marine genera Neanthes and Perinereis, the earthworm genus Pontoscolex and the freshwater genera Chaetogaster, Dero, Slavina and Stylaria, revealing cryptic species in several cases.

 

Broader impacts of the study include substantial amounts of training in molecular genetic techniques, bioinformatics and phylogenetic data analysis for principal investigator Frank Anderson, Bronwyn Williams (a female postdoctoral research, now a curator at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences) as well as one PhD student, two MS students, and eight undergraduates at Southern Illinois University. Findings from this project have been presented in multiple venues, including oral and poster presentations at national and international meetings and invited seminars at two universities. This project also formed the basis for ongoing, twice-yearly presentations about marine invertebrates and the Great Barrier Reef to academically talented third-grade students at a public school in Carbondale, Illinois.
